results.title: Providing for independence in learning (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Robert E. Gilbert and Kismet Films
results.brief_description: Outlines the need for providing children with the opportunity and skills for independent learning. Points out the role of the school and the library in developing self direction skills and providing opportunities for the disadvantaged child.

results.title: Proud years
results.creator_credit: George C. Stoney and Potomac Films
results.brief_description: Shows steps that can be taken to help old people to lead active, useful lives; explores the daily problems of old age and discusses the problems that arise from needless inactivity in old age.

results.title: Proud ships: A glimpse of the Shell tanker at work
results.creator_credit: Philip Armitage and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: One-fifth of the merchant ships afloat consists of tankers which form a floating chain between the oilfields of the world and the consumer. The film centres round a single tanker - the “Liparus” - on her normal run, introducing her officers and some of her crew. The modern takner is a large and handsome vessel and special care is devoted to ensuring good living conditions for officers and men. Because of possible danger there is a fixed routine of weekly boat drill, and fire-drills are taken seriously. As a result tankers are “the best bet there is on the insurance market”.

results.title: Protozoa: one-celled animals
results.brief_description: Dr Roman Vishniac, scientist and microphotographer, identifies pseudopods, flagelettes, and ciliates, showing how they move, eat and reproduce. Provides examples of symbiosis, parasitism, and colonial organisations.

results.title: Protestant spirit USA
results.creator_credit: Mischa Scorer, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Long Search”.
Ronald Eyre investigates Protestantism in three of its guises in America today. The two main groups of mainstream and fundamentalist are explored. The Fundamentalist groups are experiencing a startling growth, and the mainstream protestant churches are in decline. The Fundamentalists rely heavily on a literal interpretation of the Bible and on saving souls, whilst the traditional churches see religion as an outward directing force to improve the lot of humankind. Ronald Eyre concludes with a visit to a Black Baptist Church in a poor area where the needs of the poor are addressed, and the idea that Protestantism is the impulse to keep things moving.

results.title: Protein synthesis
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Biology students will quickly grasp the importance of proteins as the basic building blocks of life and the fundamental role that protein synthesis plays in all living things from these six 10 minute episodes. Each episode explores one aspect of the process, from the manufacture of DNA to the roles of the messenger and transfer RNA. Computer animation provides clear demonstrations that make this complex subject easily understood. The programs include: 1. “Protein: the stuff of life” 2. “DNA: the molecule of heredity messenger” 3. “DNA: Replication: the repeating formula” 4. “RNA Synthesis: the genetic messenger maker” 5. Transfer RNA: the genetic” 6. “Ribosomal RNA: the protein.

results.title: Protein structure and functions
results.brief_description: The film shows that life requires protein as a structure to maintain it and as a catalyst for the system of chemical reactions necessary for life. Shows the molecular structure of protein and its function. Presents protein as a polymer of amino acids and shows that amino acid side chains determine the structural configuration and chemical or enzymatic activity of protein.

results.title: Protectionism (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Global Economy”.
One of the most debated issues for economists is the value of protectionist policies in maintaining and developing national industries. This second episode of the Open Learning economics course examines the pros and cons of protectionism by examining the conflict over trade restrictions placed on sales of US grain to European Community markets. It includes interviews with US business people and with representatives of the French farmers who violently oppossed any easing of European trade restrictions. The second part of the episode explores the various other forms protectionism takes apart from explicit import quotas and taxes. It examines the history of the Voluntary Export Restraint agreement between Japan and the United States which was co-signed in 1981. The agreement offered some protection to an American automobile industry struggling to survive the effects of exploding petroleum prices in the 1970’s. The example delineates the conflict between economic theories which identify people primarily as consumers and those which identify people as labour.
